search_result.title: Indian River School District looks for fix after failed tax increase
search_result.text:
The Indian River School District will not expand its campuses after district voters rejected a tax increase to pay for the area's rapidly growing student population.

Officials are now looking for ways to cope with overcrowding in schools, which teachers say is affecting students' learning environment.

“We are obviously disappointed ... but we respect the wishes of our residents," said Indian River School District Superintendent Mark Steele following the referendum's failure on Tuesday.

More than 3,100 residents voted on Feb. 5 for the tax increase, but more than 3,840 rejected it, according to the district's unofficial vote count.

The district is considering hosting another referendum in 2019, and plans to discuss one at its next school board meeting on Feb. 25.

The failed tax increase aimed to address overcrowding in the majority of the district's 16 schools. Those numbers are expected to keep growing.

The failed referendum would have added a new Sussex Central High School building, as well as eight classrooms to Indian River High School and four classrooms to Selbyville Middle School. The additions would have cost $140.84 million, $14.29 million and $3.38 million, respectively. The new high school building would have been built next to the school's current location.

"With our total enrollment projected to grow by more than 1,700 students during the next six years, we are still faced with a shortage of classroom space at several schools," Steele said.

The district says there is a "good chance" it will have to add outdoor classrooms, which look like double-wide trailers, on some of its campuses. Had the referendum passed, the district says, it would not have had to add as many — or keep them as long.

The district does not currently have outdoor classrooms on its campuses. They could appear by next year, officials say.

Sussex Central will likely be the first to see outdoor classrooms on its campus. But other campuses that might need them do not have the physical space, Steele said.

“We’re going to have to look at every space-usage thing that we can think of,” Steele said. “We’re going to have to resolve it somehow.”

Teachers, students struggling with overcrowding

Sussex Central High School is at the forefront of the school district’s case. It is so crowded, Steele said, that students "shuffle" through the school building "like a large group of zombies."

The failed referendum would have replaced the high school's current building. The new building would have held 2,200 students.

The current high school building is meant to hold about 1,500 students, but is currently cramming in more than 1,660 students.

Those at the high school say it has struggled with its growing population for several years, and it has since gotten worse.

“We’re certainly bursting at the seams now,” said Bruce Copeland, who teaches 12th-grade English at Sussex Central. “It really does make teaching and interacting with everyone much more difficult.”

Copeland averages about 30 students per class, and says he struggles to get “one-on-one time” with all of his students to make sure each is absorbing the curriculum. Copeland said he has 34 desks squeezed into his classroom, which in years prior have all been filled.

“There’s no way, in a 70-minute period, that I can do that with every single student,” Copeland said. “Not anything meaningful. Not anything that’s really going to stick. We can kind of skim the surface and touch on a few things, but we can’t dig deep.”

Teachers are working to accommodate to the large class sizes, Copeland said, but have limited time and resources for teaching material that they think could “enhance” or “enrich” the lesson.

Teachers are also more likely to spend less time on grading papers if they total 120 students across their classes.

“I’m going to kind of skim through and spend maybe 6 or 7 minutes instead of that 10 or 12 minutes that I would like to,” Copeland said. “It really forces me to narrow my focus and, really, not give a true assessment.”

Plus, the more people in a classroom at once, the more likely someone is to be distracted.

“All it takes is two or three people to pull out their phones or make some random comment,” Copeland said. “If you have over 30 students, the chances are that’s going to happen much more frequently.”

Support local journalism: 6 benefits of a Delmarva Now digital subscription

Other teachers are likewise managing 30-plus students per class, Copeland said. He added that physical education teachers sometimes have to keep track of 40 students per class.

“It’s easy to lose track,” Copeland said.

It’s not just in the classroom. The overcrowding affects students throughout the day, Copeland said.

Teachers and students have trouble even running to the bathroom between classes because hallways are so crowded, Copeland said. At lunchtime, students may have to wait in line for more than 10 minutes before getting their food.

Lunch periods at the high school are 30 minutes long. The earliest begins shortly before 11:40 a.m. and the latest begins at 12:55 p.m. The district says that it may have to begin adding earlier or later lunch shifts if enrollment continues to grow.

“They barely have the time to actually eat their lunch and socialize before they have to run off to the next class,” Copeland said.

Announcements or emails are sometimes sent out to excuse students for being tardy to class because they didn’t get lunch on time, he said.

Even if they do have time to eat, students still have to fight the flooded hallways just to get to class, those familiar with the school say.

“We do have a really good environment here, a healthy environment, a diverse population,” Copeland said. “But, typically, when things are crowded, that raises tensions. That may raise tempers (between students) as well.”

The crowded building makes some students less patient, Copeland said.

“Instead of taking the time to actually engage with each other and to learn from each other, I think that everyone is in a hurry,” Copeland said. “They don’t have time for that extra stuff. When, in my opinion, that extra stuff is where they have that opportunity to learn and to grow.”

Sussex Central High School is not the only Indian River school dealing with overcrowding.

Nine of the district's 16 schools already exceed capacity, meaning the student population is more than 90 percent of the building occupancy. That includes the three schools that would have been expanded via February's failed referendum.

"When you have 90 percent in the building ... legitimately, you're full," Steele told Delmarva Now in December.

Sussex Central is at 111 percent capacity. Indian River High School is over capacity at 95 percent with 950 students, and is estimated to reach more than 100 percent capacity by 2022. Selbyville Middle School is at 102 percent capacity with about 740 students.

“We haven’t given up,” Copeland said. “We would just love to have more community support in doing so. What we’re doing here affects everyone.”

Other schools crowded, too

The district has had similar referendums in recent years, including one that passed in March 2017 to fund additional school services and address enrollment growth.

Before that, the district failed to pass that same referendum in November 2016 after the district's chief financial officer was put on leave and a subsequent state audit, released less than a week before the vote, revealed several instances of "inappropriate" spending on items such as designer bracelets.

Since then, the district has implemented transparency efforts, including a budget oversight committee formed when Steele became superintendent in 2017.

Indian River isn't the only school system grappling with enrollment changes.

The Cape Henlopen School District has seen a near-1,500-student increase in enrollment since 2001. Like Indian River, the district expects that enrollment to keep growing.

In March, Cape Henlopen was able to get voter approval to add elementary schools and a middle school, as well as additional space for its high school, within the next several years.

The countywide Sussex Technical School District, meanwhile, hopes to reinstate its 1,400-student enrollment cap during this legislative session that began last month. The state General Assembly in 2015 mandated the vocational high school lower that cap to 1,250 students as a cost-saving measure, among other requirements.

The district wants that cap lifted, especially as applications grow.

"We had more than 800 applicants this year, a record number, and are able to accept less than 300," said Sussex Tech Superintendent Stephen Guthrie in a statement Wednesday.

Sussex Tech thinks it can make the case, since Indian River is grappling with overcapacity in its schools.

Legislators spoke with the Sussex Tech board members about the enrollment policy on Wednesday. It’s unclear what lawmakers will decide for the vocational district.

Guthrie said that any change would be “phased in gradually over time," but has suggested that an increase in enrollment could help "alleviate" Indian River's overcrowding.

But any enrollment increase for the high school would likely be less than 200 students — a fraction of the several hundred spaces that Indian River says it needs.

“I don’t see where that’s helpful to us at all,” Steele said, adding that Sussex Tech admits students from across the county.

More:Too many students in one building? Vote to decide on Indian River school expansion

search_result.title: 20 years after Tom Capano arrest, juror breaks silence on Anne ...
search_result.text:
Could a dead woman's body really fit into a fishing cooler?

Erin Reilly Lee, also known as Juror No. 8 on the capital murder trial of wealthy Wilmington lawyer Thomas J. Capano, was trying to answer that question when she wedged herself into the white Igloo cooler that played a grisly role in one of the most sensational and dramatic court cases in Delaware history.

It was a key piece of evidence in the haunting case that still resonates 20 years after Capano's November 1997 arrest because it echoes current headlines: men in positions of power trying to exert absolute control over their alleged victims.

The 12-week trial kept the public riveted from October 1998 to January 1999.

Capano had apparently stuffed the 5-foot-10-inch body of his younger, secret girlfriend, Anne Marie Fahey, into the ice chest after she was shot to death at his home with a gun bought by Deborah A. MacIntyre, one of his other longtime mistresses. Capano, married with four daughters, would later blame MacIntyre for Fahey's death.

The day after Fahey's mysterious June 1996 death, Capano, with the help of his youngest brother, Gerry, used the cooler to transport Fahey's body to Gerry's boat Summer Wind at Stone Harbor, New Jersey.

Summer Wind motored east about 60 to 75 miles, Gerry testified, where he then gave his brother an anchor and chain and turned his back on the scene unfolding on deck. Gerry told the court that Tom Capano vomited, then put a body into the ocean. According to testimony, he turned around in time to see a human foot sink into the deep waters.

Tom Capano told his attorney Joseph S. Oteri that he first rejected putting Fahey's body into a brand-new garbage can. Instead, Capano used a 40½-gallon cooler, purchased two months before Fahey's death. Capano’s brother Joseph, who died of a heart attack in 2015, said he told Tom to buy the cooler as a gift for brother Gerry.

Two and half years after Fahey died, the jury hearing Capano's murder trial was sequestered at the Hilton Wilmington/Christiana near Stanton.

Deliberations lasted three days.

Capano case:For complete coverage, including past stories, videos and more

"Honestly, a lot of people would be surprised to know that when we first went in to deliberate, first thing we did was take a poll to see where everybody stood and it was half and half," said Lee, who counted herself among the not-guilty votes.

Lee recalled one of the jurors said: "'We should see if she could really just fit [into the cooler].'"

Lee, 28 years old at the time and known as Erin Reilly, was just a few inches shorter and weighed about the same as Fahey. Sitting at a big table in a hotel conference room, she felt all eyes on her.

Although one of her fellow jurors said she didn't need to do it, Lee agreed to climb into the 3-foot-8-inch hard-plastic cooler that served as a makeshift coffin. She left her high heels on to compensate for Fahey's height.

"This is important," Lee remembers telling herself. "It's important for everybody. It's important for me because I didn't know."

Jurors helped the young woman into the cooler and then watched as Lee tried to "squoosh myself smaller" to give others an accurate picture.

"My eyes were closed for sure," she said. "I'm not sure why. Probably because I didn't want to see."

As jurors attempted to shut the cooler's lid, Lee recalls being surrounded by a darkness she had never known.

In court testimony, Capano said he laid Fahey's body into the cooler on her side. He said he pushed her knees into a fetal position but insisted he broke no bones to make her body fit. Capano also said he had wrapped her body in a cotton blanket.

But Lee and the other jurors soon learned it wasn't the gentle tuck-in Capano had described.

As Lee squirmed inside the cooler, the lid wouldn't close. And that's when some of the jurors realized Fahey's bones might have been broken, or worse, to make the corpse fit.

The macabre situation, and the enormity of what had happened to Fahey, suddenly became real and overwhelming.

"OK," Lee remembers another juror saying. "That's enough. Let's get her out."

After what seemed like an eternity, a traumatized Lee asked a bailiff to escort her to her hotel bedroom. Lee sat alone and sobbed.

Tears fell for Fahey, a troubled, insecure, single woman who wanted to end an off-and-on, three-year affair with the then 46-year-old Capano, a controlling, jealous, married lover who wouldn't let her walk away.

As she cried, Lee, only two years younger than the victim, said she spoke to Fahey: "I'm just so sorry. I'm so sorry that this happened to you."

The climb into the cooler-turned-casket convinced Erin Reilly Lee and the jury of five other women and six men that Capano was a manipulative liar, a cold-blooded killer.

It was Capano who shot Fahey, the jury determined.

William Swain Lee, the Superior Court judge who presided over the trial, said he was walking on the beach Saturday, January 16, 1999, when his beeper went off.

"I had to run about a mile to get back to my car, drive to my house to get to a telephone, and call in," he said.

The jury had reached a verdict.

"We had to go find everyone," Judge Lee added. "The lawyers were in different restaurants in a three-state area. So, the soonest we could get together was Sunday morning and I did not think that once it was announced that the jury had reached a verdict that we could take a day off.

"We needed to get it out, so I scheduled the unusual Sunday morning session."

Sunday morning the jury found Capano, then 49, guilty of the first-degree murder of 30-year-old Fahey, a scheduling secretary for then-Gov. Tom Carper.

Judge Lee sentenced Capano to death.

It was a stunning fall from grace for the prominent Wilmington attorney who had once counseled a Delaware mayor and governor and was the privileged, eldest son of a well-known Italian custom home builder. In just 31 months, Capano had gone from admired power broker to pariah.

From Fahey's disappearance on June 27, 1996, to Capano's conviction on Jan. 17, 1999, the public devoured every morsel of information uncovered. The trial spawned four books and a 2001 TV movie that starred Mark Harmon as Capano.

More:Prosecutor Colm Connolly: Tom Capano tried to take a hit out on me

More:ARCHIVE: Search set for Carper assistant

More:ARCHIVE: 300 Join in Fahey search

More:ARCHIVE: FBI search for Fahey may go on

The case was revived again in 2006 when Capano's death sentence was overturned. A life sentence was his punishment.

By then, years of confinement and isolation on death row had begun to take its toll. Capano, overweight with sallow skin and a wispy, white beard, no longer resembled the fit, polished, man-about-town he had once been.

"He had gained a massive amount of weight since the trial," said Colm F. Connolly, the unflappable federal prosecutor who led the investigation and endured Capano's intense hatred, which included verbal attacks and, at one point, plans to put a hit on him.

Capano died of a heart attack on Sept. 19, 2011, at age 61 at the Vaughn Correctional Center near Smyrna, where he was serving the life sentence.

"He ate himself to death; there's no question about it," Judge Lee said.

"His father died of a heart attack, he knew he had a heart condition. Once his appeals ran out, I think it was suicide by food," said Lee, who retired from the bench nine months after the trial and now lives near Rehoboth Beach.

More:'This is Tom, Tom Capano,' said the man on the phone

Capano's obituary said he "was many things to many people, but most of all he was a loving father who will be greatly missed by his [four] daughters."

It touched upon Capano's love of music and places in Wilmington, some no longer open. The man the family called "Tommy," the obituary said, was known for "his impeccable taste: blasting old classics – the Temptations, the Four Seasons, Aretha Franklin, Frank Sinatra, or the Rolling Stones – at full volume while waiting to pick up pizza from Gallucio's; allowing his daughters to skip school on their birthdays for a luxurious lunch at the Rodney Square Club; ordering an assortment of mouthwatering seafood from DiNardo's with extra Old-Bay seasoning."

The obituary did not mention the murder conviction.

More:ARCHIVE: Capano held in murder of Anne Marie Fahey

More:ARCHIVE: The Capanos: A house in ruins

Twenty years after he was arrested, the Thomas J. Capano murder mystery continues to fascinate because of its alluring – and grim – elements: sex, power, wealth, politics, secret affairs, lurid moments and an extraordinary reversal of fortune that wouldn't ring true if written in a crime novel.

"It was amazing the twists and turns throughout the case, especially during the trial," said Connolly, then an assistant U.S. attorney who had never before tried a murder case.

Working with Ferris W. Wharton, a seasoned state prosecutor with nearly 20 years' experience running murder trials, Connolly and his team won a first-degree murder conviction and a death sentence – even though there was no body, no witnesses to the killing and no found murder weapon.

More:Prosecutor Ferris Wharton: The moment I remember the most is the cooler

It would be Connolly's one-and-only murder trial. He is now managing partner of the Wilmington law office of Morgan Lewis.

"I do think the reality is, and I'll have to accept, it was the ultimate professional experience I will ever have, and I was very young to have had it," said Connolly, who was 33 when the trial began.

On the other side of the courtroom, Capano's defense was made up of four well-known criminal defense lawyers who frequently squabbled with their client.

More:Defense attorney Maurer: I wanted to withdraw from Tom Capano case

"Often dubbed the ‘Dream Team,’ the defense in this case became a nightmare," Eugene J. Maurer Jr. wrote in an essay for The News Journal.

"Tom was an impossible client, pushing the envelope at all times and making the representation quite unpleasant. Ethical boundaries were of no consideration to him in formulating his defense strategy, as was demonstrated by the evidence at trial."

Added Maurer: "Instead of a challenging and fulfilling professional experience, the representation of Tom Capano was one of the most depressing and disappointing professional experiences of my life."

Joseph S. Oteri, the Boston lawyer who led Capano’s “Dream Team,” was more blunt about representing Capano: “I made a bad mistake in taking a lawyer for a client.”

Oteri said he is usually the man in charge. But Capano’s insistence on running the case got in the way.

“He was taking advice from people in the jail rather than the people he was paying for and it was tough,” Oteri told The News Journal. “It didn't make me feel anything but pissed off because I kept saying, ‘You're paying me an enormous fee and you're not listening to me. How stupid can you be?’”

“‘Nah, nah,’” Oteri quoted Capano as saying. “We're doing fine. We're all right."

Judge Lee said it was tough going for the defense.

“Capano was always confident he was going to win and it was clear he considered himself smarter than his excellent group of lawyers,” the judge said.

More:ARCHIVE: Cooler found in Fahey case

More:ARCHIVE: FBI sought weapons in Capano's home

Anne Marie Fahey wanted – and believed – she had escaped Capano's dominance and intimidation.

"For one whole year, I allowed someone to take control of every decision of my life," she wrote in her diary April 7, 1996 – one of the final entries.

Her plan was to move forward with a kind man younger than Capano. It was not to be. A little more than two months after that last entry, Fahey was reported missing.

Fahey's remains have never been found. One of the few places to mourn and remember her is a memorial bench erected in 2006 that sits in Wilmington's Brandywine Park. “In our hearts forever,” reads the inscription.

More:ARCHIVE: Power broker now pariah

More:ARCHIVE: Guilty as charged

Evidence from the case, relatively untouched since 1999, today collects dust in a vault at the Leonard L. Williams Justice Center on Wilmington's King Street, formerly called the New Castle County Courthouse.

It serves as both an elegy and a 1990s time capsule with cassettes and videotapes of interviews with Capano's brothers, handwritten lists of state and defense witnesses –– and pieces of a life that ended much too soon.

Usually, evidence is given away to the defense or destroyed after a defendant’s death.

"This is the only dead person I still have evidence for," said Colleen Redmond of the Prothonotary's office as she looked over items from the trial.

"The court said we shouldn't get rid of it," despite Capano’s death six years ago, she said.

Folded up is a then-fashionable, size 6, cream-and-blue floral Laura Ashley dress. It is possibly the long, springtime dress Fahey bought to wear to Winterthur's Point-to-Point steeplechase races with her boyfriend Michael Scanlan, then community affairs chief of MBNA America Bank, whom she hoped to marry.

Authorities believe one of the reasons Capano killed Fahey was his jealousy of Scanlan, a devout Catholic who testified his relationship with Fahey was not sexual. Scanlan didn't know about Fahey's involvement with Capano until after her death.

According to his Linkedin profile, Scanlan left MBNA in June 1999 and is now assistant headmaster at St. Benedict's Preparatory School in Newark, New Jersey. He also works as a photographer shooting high school sports, portraits and does some commercial work.

Gone from the evidence vault are Fahey's wallet, jewelry box and the diary that gave investigators much-needed clues that pointed to her murderer. Her family took those items years ago, court officials say.

But, still in the vault are the copies of letters mistress MacIntyre wrote daily to Capano in prison before she turned on him in February 1998 and became a key witness for the prosecution. Some of the letters from the divorced MacIntyre, a Capano girlfriend for more than 15 years, begin with the greeting, "Hey Handsome."

More:ARCHIVE: Death for Capano

More:ARCHIVE: Capano found dead in prison

Finally, there are two 162-quart Igloo ice coolers – one used as a demonstration in court, and one the actual cooler, and Fahey's coffin. Inside of it rests a 12-gauge shotgun.

In one of the case's most surprising twists, the abandoned cooler was found floating in the Atlantic Ocean by four fishermen about a week after Gerry Capano unsuccessfully tried to sink it by firing a slug into it with a 12-gauge Mossberg shotgun.

The fishermen, who kept it in a shed, turned it over to prosecutors the day after reading media accounts of Capano's arrest in November 1997.

Judge Lee, in a recent interview, said it is astonishing that the cooler had been discovered off Indian River Inlet, 100 miles from where it had been thrown into the ocean.

"It's certainly stranger than fiction, the truth," Judge Lee said. "My reaction was Tom Capano should know there really is a God now.”

Connolly said bringing the actual cooler into court on Dec. 2, 1998, just before the state rested its case, still stays with him nearly 20 years later.

"I will never forget that moment. It was dead silent. It was a dark day, so not much light was coming in the windows of the courtroom," he said. "Ferris and I walked the cooler in front of the jury. It was as if we were pallbearers carrying the coffin into the court."

Juror Erin Reilly Lee, no relation to Judge William Swain Lee, still gets chills seeing pictures of the Igloo cooler.

“Oh my gosh,” she told The News Journal after viewing photos. “You talk about divine intervention. There’s a great example.”

Wharton, now a Superior Court judge, said the court retains all the evidence while there's still ongoing litigation. But, after a defendant's death, it is then offered to the defense and/or destroyed after a period of time.

"It would surprise me if they got rid of all that evidence just because of the interest in it. People kept wanting to look at it for various reasons," Wharton said.

On the anniversary of Capano's arrest, The News Journal has asked some principal players to recall their memories of the investigation and trial.

Essays and "As Told To" stories include thoughts from Connolly and Wharton, defense attorneys Maurer and Oteri, retired Judge Lee, former News Journal reporter Valerie Helmbreck, former Wilmington restaurateur Anthony Stella, juror Erin Reilly Lee and psychiatrist Neil Kaye.

Time has a way of fraying memories and, 20 years later, some participants have slightly different versions of the same story and others share never heard before details. The News Journal has tried to clarify and add context to some of their words using information from court records and articles from the paper's archives.

Still, some of the people who were caught up in Capano's web of lies are more than ready to put the past behind them.

MacIntyre is remarried and now working at the American Society of Cytopathology, a nonprofit organization in Wilmington. The office is near the old Daniel L. Herrmann Courthouse, now the home of the law firm Young Conaway Stargatt & Taylor. In the old courthouse two decades ago, she talked about her longtime affair with Capano and about buying a gun for him six weeks before Fahey died.

MacIntyre, known now as Debby MacIntyre Sheldon, declined to be interviewed.

When reached by The News Journal via email on Nov. 13, she replied: "I have no interest in talking about the case. Best regards, Debby MacIntyre Sheldon."

The Fahey family declined to be interviewed or write about their memories.

After Anne Marie’s disappearance, her brothers, sister and extended family said they decided as a group to talk to media to keep attention on the case.

While family members were concerned they would appear as seeking attention, they felt it was proper to keep the case in the public eye, and keep pressure on the Capano family.

After the trial, the Faheys decided as a group to stop talking to the media, and to draw no more attention to themselves.

Members of the Capano family reached by The News Journal declined to comment.

The Thomas J. Capano case captivated Delaware that's known, for better or worse, as a clannish community, especially concerning its native sons and daughters.

"What's your name? Where did you grow up? Where did you go to high school?" are frequent questions that start a connect-the-dots conversation about common acquaintances.

Ties could be made to Capano and Fahey, both from large Wilmington-area families with high-profile jobs.

“You have Anne Marie Fahey who worked for the governor and she had a family that a lot of people knew. She was very attractive and very personable, and young,” Wharton said.

“Everybody knew of the Capanos. He (Tom) was very prominent. He had been a prosecutor, a public defender, the administrative assistant to the Wilmington mayor. Capano had been a partner in a couple big law firms, Morris James and Saul Ewing. He had been the governor's legal counsel. And everybody knows of Capano because of all the development that they did,” Wharton said.

For a few days in the summer of 1996, the disappearance of Anne Marie Fahey seemed to be little more than a missing person case.

Years before being selected as a juror, Erin Reilly Lee remembers longtime friends talking about search parties being formed for a missing woman who’d grown up near her childhood neighborhood.

Fahey, a pretty and vivacious woman, went to dinner on June 27 with Capano at Ristorante Panorama on Front Street in Philadelphia. The eatery, which is still there, was considered one of the city's great wine destinations and featured classic Italian cuisine.

Capano, married for 24 years, had recently separated from his wife. Going to Philadelphia was his routine. He had multiple mistresses and liked to take them on dates far away from his home and nosy, prying eyes in New Castle County.

"Wilmington is a small town, a gossipy place," he said on the witness stand on Dec. 17, 1998.

According to a waitress that night, dinner wasn’t going so well. Capano ordered the food without consulting Fahey. They drank wine and picked at calamari and bruschetta, both looking miserable.

Fahey had met Capano in 1993, and wrote in her diary she fell in love with him on her January 1994 birthday. He lavished her with attention, gifts and visits to expensive restaurants. Capano also knew some of Fahey’s hidden secrets, such as she suffered from eating disorders.

In September 1995, Fahey met Scanlan, who was unmarried and closer to her age. She wanted to end the affair with Capano. But when they left the Panorama restaurant at about 9:30 p.m. June 27, it would be the last time Fahey was seen in public.

Two days later, family and friends, concerned that she failed to keep a dinner date with Scanlan at her brother’s house, went to her 1718 Washington St. apartment on the third-floor and found it empty. They also find a diary Fahey kept where she wrote that Capano was “a jealous maniac.”

Capano was questioned twice on June 30 at his $2,000 a month rental home at 2302 Grant Ave. in the city’s Highlands neighborhood. Police looked through his home and a Jeep Grand Cherokee, but, at that time, found no signs of Fahey.

Missing person photos of Fahey, a blue-eyed beauty with dark, curly hair, and yellow ribbons begin appearing on telephone poles, trees and signs around Wilmington. A billboard went up on I-95. Her family started a vigil on the front porch of the Washington Street apartment. They frequently met up at O’Friel’s Irish Pub, a then-popular bar in downtown Wilmington. Time marches on and the bar has closed. The building went up for sale in 2001 and later became a salon and spa.

President Bill Clinton called Fahey’s boss, Gov. Tom Carper, now Delaware's senior senator, whom Fahey had worked for since her 1991 graduation from Dover's Wesley College.

On July 5, 1996, Clinton said the federal government would help with the search. However, it seems he forgot to notify the U.S. Attorney’s Office in Delaware, according to Connolly.

“I was in the grocery store, the Acme on [U.S.] 202, and I ran into Judge Greg Sleet, who was the U.S. attorney, my boss. The lead story of The News Journal that day was President Clinton offered federal assistance. Judge Greg Sleet and I laughed because Greg Sleet was the U.S. attorney, so he was the chief federal law enforcement officer, and nobody had contacted him,” Connolly said.

“If you were really going to get the feds involved, you would contact him. He said, 'Well, I'll call over to Wilmington, and we'll offer our services.' The next working day, July 8, the FBI called us.”

State prosecutors later agreed to bow out of the picture. A federal grand jury investigation, which had to remain secret, began.

Connolly, leading a team of investigators, began methodically chipping away at the investigation by conducting interviews, searches, and combing through phone and financial records.

On July 26, 1996, he and Wilmington police investigator Bob Donovan discovered, through financial records, Capano had made a purchase at a company listed as Wallpaper Warehouse two days after Fahey was last seen in public alive.

“I knew enough about Capano at that point, because we're a week or so into the investigation, I know that he was not the kind of guy who does home improvements himself. I know he's living in a rental house, so he wouldn't be buying wallpaper. I thought it was very weird,” Connolly said.

They called the number, the person who answered said, “Airbase Carpet.”

“Immediately, Bob and I looked at each other, and thought, 'Oh my goodness, he rolled her up in the carpet. That's what this is all about,'" Connolly said.

Investigators also learn later Capano has replaced a love seat, and an employee of Capano’s brother, developer Louis L. Capano Jr., tells them on July 1 he was ordered to have a half-filled trash bin emptied from a Concord Pike construction site.

They also find Capano has visited a Happy Harry’s store in Trolley Square on June 30 and asks about a blood remover.

Investigators search Capano’s house for 11 hours on July 31 and find two tiny drops of blood that they later learn matches a sample of Fahey’s blood plasma.

A search takes place Aug. 12-16 of two local landfills to try and find the rug, sofa and other evidence. The search is messy, and officers come up empty.

A turning point arrives in October 1997 when federal agents raid the Wilmington home of Capano's brother Gerry and find illegal drugs and guns.

Capano's brothers Gerald and Louis agree to began cooperating with the authorities in November 1997 to avoid federal charges.

Gerry becomes a cooperating witness. He tells authorities that he took out his boat, Summer Wind, and helped Capano dispose of a body in the Atlantic Ocean on Friday, June 28, 1996. He provided other incriminating evidence, including getting rid of a sofa with a basketball-sized bloodstain, and a rug.

His brother Louis says the stained sofa and rug were put into a dumpster on one of his properties.

After the brothers began cooperation with the prosecution as part of a plea agreement, Capano is arrested on Nov. 12, 1997.

Wharton said Capano seemed to think he could get away with murder. Why?

“Because he always had. He had done a lot of bad things that nobody ever called him into account for and he thought he could control things,” Wharton said.

“He thought the investigation would be confined to the Wilmington police looking for a missing person which they were never going to be able to find.”

In February 1998, Deborah MacIntyre, a longtime Capano girlfriend, also signs a plea agreement and becomes a witness for the prosecution. She shares that she bought a .22-caliber gun at Capano’s request. It has never been recovered. MacIntyre also turns over her steamy letters she wrote to Capano and begins taping phone calls he makes to her from prison.

An outraged Capano asks an inmate, Nicholas Perillo, to arrange to burglarize MacIntyre’s house to intimidate her. The burglary never happened.

Defense attorney Maurer will later accuse MacIntyre of firing the shot that killed Fahey. She vehemently denies it.

The case takes a twist when Capano attorney Joseph A. Hurley announces in early April 1998 he's quitting the defense team. Hurley, who had been friends with Capano for at least eight years, at that time would give no reason saying only that he will take it "to his grave."

On Friday – 19 years later – he shared for the first time exclusively with The News Journal that a moment of moral clarity came to him while attending a funeral Mass at St. Helena's Catholic Church in Penny Hill for public defender James F. McCloskey Jr.

Hurley sat in a pew, in his childhood church, and said he had a conversation with God.

"I can only surmise that there was something making me feel like I was falling into an evil pit and this conversation, if that's what you have with God, [went] 'Joe, you're not like this. You can't be this way.'"

"I think I was probably facing the reality he was, in fact, guilty of premeditated murder," Hurley said.

He said he'd never asked Capano what happened the night Fahey disappeared.

"I didn't want to ask him and hear the answer," Hurley said.

He left church, went to see Capano in prison and quit the case.

No longer considering him a friend, Hurley never saw Capano again.

"Killing a human being? No. That's the end of friendship," Hurley said.

Capano’s trial begins Oct. 6, 1998, with jury selection. Capano’s attorneys try to talk him out of selecting young women.

“The last thing we wanted on a jury was women under 30 with a college education because they would identify immediately with the victim,” Boston lawyer Oteri said.

Judge Lee recalled after the women were included on the jury, he was approached by Oteri who said, "'Can I go off the record, Judge?' And I went, 'Sure. Off the record.'"

Oteri said: 'The dumb son of a bitch thinks they are going to fall in love with him.'"

Oteri told The News Journal last week that he didn't recall the conversation.

Judge Lee said he didn't know Capano when "he had the reputation of being a charming man, but in the setting in which I knew him, he was more rodent-like. He was a frightening, scary figure. There was nothing charming about him at all."

Oteri, who joined the defense team only months before the trial started, drops a bombshell in his opening statement: He says while Capano did dump Fahey’s body at sea, she died from an “outrageous, horrible, tragic accident.”

Capano claims Fahey was shot to death accidentally by MacIntyre in a jealous fit of rage, while she was attempting suicide. "His story is nonsense," Wharton said.

And it just gets keep getting stranger.

Neil S. Kaye, a psychiatrist who met Fahey hours before she meets Capano for dinner, shows up to testify in a wooden hat. It earns almost as much attention as what he has to say about Fahey’s fear of ending her relationship with Capano because of his “rage and anger.”

Keith R. Brady, who is then Delaware’s chief deputy attorney and Wharton’s superior, is called to testify about a sexual encounter he had five years earlier with MacIntyre while Capano watched. Capano has said he was supposed to golf with Brady the day after Fahey's death. Connolly questions him on the stand for the prosecution, and Oteri delves into the encounter with MacIntrye. Brady takes an unpaid leave of absence after leaving the stand.

“I don't think Keith ever really accepted the fact that he was going to be a witness. He always thought that was not going to happen,” Wharton said. “We were very discreet about that, the way we phrased our questions, but Oteri was not. Keith looked like he was a dead man up there.”

Connolly reads up on Capano’s cases when he was prosecutor and believes the Wilmington lawyer killed Fahey based on a 1976 murder Capano had prosecuted. Connolly says a man called Robert “Squeaky” Saunders shot a victim in the head, threw the body in a canal and disposed of the gun.

Connolly also continues to get under Capano’s skin. In a burst of anger, he calls Connolly “a heartless, gutless, soulless disgrace of a human being” and is removed from the courtroom.

A final last-minute surprise comes when a neighbor of MacIntyre comes forward in the remaining few days of the trial to say she saw a sobbing MacIntyre stumble out of her car on the night around when Fahey is killed. The neighbor claims the area was lit by floodlights.

But Connolly tracks down a Kennett Square, Pennsylvania, handyman who says he installed a new, brighter light fixture at MacIntyre’s house – six months after Fahey’s death.

Nearly 20 years later, the trial continues to be surreal for Erin Reilly Lee, whose willing venture into Fahey's plastic coffin helped bring focus to a divided jury and sealed Capano’s fate.

Her journey began in Trolley Square, where Lee lived nearly oblivious to the developing Capano-Fahey saga.

She received a jury duty summons but was certain there were too many similarities between her and Fahey to be picked for jury duty. Lee went to the courthouse believing she would be sent away soon.

Wharton remembers that day. “Erin Reilly was a potential juror. She came in, in a plaid sort of jumper. She could have been Anne Marie Fahey. Tall, attractive. The defense lawyers wanted to strike her, but Capano insisted on keeping her because, I think, he thought, he could charm her.”

At voir dire, the process through which potential jurors are questioned by either the judge or a lawyer, Lee was interrogated then asked to leave the courtroom. When she returned, she was stunned when the judge said she’d been selected.

“My brain just kind of stopped,” she said. “I was so shocked that I looked at him and I said, ‘I’m sorry. Excuse me, what did you say?’”

She remembers the somewhat taken aback judge reiterating that she’d been selected as a juror.

“I kind of didn’t really hear a whole lot after that because I was thinking, ‘My mom is going to kill me. How am I going to be on this trial?’” Erin Reilly Lee said.

As the monthslong trial began, Lee watched the attorneys present evidence and question witnesses who would later help her, and others jurors, reach their conclusions. This includes Connolly questioning Capano about how he placed Fahey in the cooler.

“Colm Connolly did such a phenomenal job of getting us to think about, could he really place this girl’s body into a big fishing cooler,” she said. “The way he would just keep pushing Tom.

“Tom said, ‘I had this cooler that I was going to give to my brother and I panicked and so I just figured I’d put her body in there.’ ”

But Connolly kept pushing, wanting to know – and the jurors – if the body easily fit in or if bones had to be broken to make it fit.

“When we were deliberating, it’s something that we kept coming back to,” Lee said. “You know, could she just fit?”

When Lee didn’t fit, jurors realized that Capano was lying. It made it easier to find holes in other parts of his testimony.

Connolly’s ability to bring out the anger in Capano, showed jurors another picture of the former prosecutor who, on the stand, was portraying himself as a meek man.

“Colm did a great job at letting us see [Capano’s] anger and how he could turn,” she said.

“It definitely was surprising. It’s not something I ever would even thought of happening in Wilmington, Delaware.”

search_result.text:
Smyrna police arrested a suspect Wednesday for the armed robbery of a food delivery driver in late January.

Joshua Brown, 29, of Smyrna, was arrested for wielding a knife and robbing a driver for Pat's Select Pizza & Grill, according to the Smyrna Police Department.

Around 8 p.m. Jan. 23, Smyrna police responded to the 400 block of West Vernon Street for a report of an armed robbery, police said.

Police said the Pat's Select driver was approached by a black male wearing a mask and armed with a knife and demanded money and property. The suspect then fled on foot.

Brown was arrested without incident on Monday and charged with first-degree robbery, possession of a deadly weapon during the commission of a felony, and wearing a disguise during the commission of a felony.

According to the release, Brown is in custody at the Sussex Correctional Institution in lieu of an $86,000 secured bond.

search_result.title: At what cost? School referendums splinter communities
search_result.text:
Matthew Albright, and Saranac Hale Spencer

The News Journal

Voters are set to consider three referendums statewide that would would raise almost $500 million.

School district officials say they're forced to ask for money because of the state's complex funding system.

The regular referendums have sparked tension among voters who are asked to fund education.

Spring is the time of year when education turns into politics, when school districts give residents a choice: Vote to raise property taxes or face teacher and program cuts.

Nobody — not seniors, not parents, not even school officials who say the money is desperately needed — like asking for a tax hike.

School supporters and parents bemoan the fact that educators and parents are forced to campaign for referendums, rather than focus on teaching children.

What's frequently misunderstood by citizens is that referendums are often intended only to keep the status quo, supporters say. But Delaware's complex school funding system has made it difficult to convince voters the increases are necessary to cover growing student enrollment and maintenance costs.

"There's so much time and energy that has to be poured into it, it's just hundreds and hundreds of man hours," said Eve Buckley, a Christina School District parent who is one of the volunteer leaders in an effort to pass that district's referendum on Wednesday. "And it's time you're using just in hopes of staying where we are, maybe getting a little better, not providing some big new idea. The process is a real drain."

Brandywine and Cape Henlopen also are seeking voters' approval that day. The three referendums combined would raise almost $500 million.

The success of those votes comes down to whether district officials can coax enough parents with children in public schools to go to the polls. They must outnumber those who don't feel they have a stake in the schools or who feel districts should do more to prove they deserve a tax increase.

"If I go to my boss and haven't done what I'm supposed to ... I don't ask for a raise," said Susan Welsh, who wants to see Christina begin to improve student test scores and find efficiencies before she votes in favor. "I love my child enough to vote 'no' and hold them [the district] accountable to raising the ranking before I give them a raise."

District supporters say referendums aren't a luxury. They are a necessity.

Money that pays for schools is a mix of state, federal and local funds. While the state's portion grows as districts enroll more students, the local portion comes from property taxes that don't increase to match growing costs.

If districts don't get the money to cover those costs, the results can be demoralizing, Buckley says.

"You want to think you're part of a community that is at least reasonably supportive of public education, and then something like what happened last year takes place," she said. "And then you start to worry about this negative feedback loop, where people think the district isn't worthy, so then we have to cut budgets. And that means the schools suffer, and the perception only gets reinforced."

Acting Christina Superintendent Bob Andrzejewski says its dangerous to leave districts without a steady, reliable base of funding.

"There are no reruns when it comes to education," he said. "If a student misses out on important educational services because there's no money, you can't go back and make that up later."

Christina is seeking about $16 million, which would amount to roughly $192 a year more in taxes for the average homeowner, according to the district. That money would be used to plug some of the holes left after the district slashed $9 million from its budget last year and would also add some new programs.

Brandywine is asking taxpayers for money to cover operating expenses, for work on school buildings and to put synthetic turf on its athletic fields. It estimates that an average home-owner would pay an extra $243 per year for the next three years and $206 per year after the $1.7 million turf project will be done. The district needs $19.3 million for the building projects and $9.5 million for operating expenses.

The referendum in Cape Henlopen is a little different – it is asking voters for money that would be used strictly for building two elementary schools and doing work on two others, which is the last phase in a 20-year, long-term plan that the district committed itself to in 1999. The total cost for the project is $154.5 million, but local taxpayers are being asked to shoulder $48.4 million of it.

Swaying the public

The base of the bloc that typically votes against referendums is believed to be older residents who don't have children, don't directly benefit from the tax increases and are often on fixed incomes.

Older residents vote more than younger residents. And low-income families are less likely to vote than more affluent families, who may not send their children to traditional public schools, Buckley said.

That stacks referendums against the districts.

"It's a huge challenge, no question," Buckley said.

In Christina's first referendum last year, when voters slapped down a tax increase by an almost three-to-one margin, turnout in more affluent suburban areas dwarfed turnout in poorer urban areas.

STORY: Robocalls used in Christina schools referendum

STORY: Wilmington redistricting plan advances on shaky ground



In five polling places in Wilmington, there were a total of 258 votes. At a single suburban polling place – McVey Elementary, just off the University of Delaware campus – more than 556 people voted.

The vote failed 2,119 – 6,076.

When Christina took a second shot with a smaller referendum last year, the district made more energetic efforts to get the word out to voters, and turnout evened out somewhat. The referendum failed again, but this time by less than 900 votes out of more than 11,000.

"The support's there," said Brian Stephan, a parent with two children in Christina and co-chair of the district's referendum steering committee. "It's just tapping into it and letting them know where to be and what you're voting for."

Part of the problem, supporters say, is that the state's school finance system is so complicated.

Stephan points out that school referendums are the only time residents get to choose whether to tax themselves. For other taxes, elected representatives choose when to raise rates; citizens vote those representatives out if they don't like their choices.

"It's the one chance that people get, so they tend to vent some of their frustrations," he said. "It doesn't just become about school taxes, it's all taxes. And that makes it hard for us."

Referendum opponents do frequently bring up other tax proposals.

"The governor wants to put more money in for the gas tax, he wants to give more money to the casinos," said Marie Lulfs, a 76-year-old Christina resident. "Everybody wants more money, and where are they getting it from? The taxpayer."

What's at stake

Nobody knows the impacts of a failed referendum quite like Christina parents and teachers.

After voters twice rejected tax increases last year, the district made more than $9 million in cuts, laying off 78 teachers and 14 aides.

Stephan's daughter's first-grade class has 37 students, far more than last year.

"That has been an extreme challenge for her teacher and for her," Stephan said. "You can just tell when she comes home from school."

Supporters like Stephan say it is hard to make voters understand that operating referendums don't necessarily mean a district is seeking new goodies. In some cases, like Christina's, they are simply asking for enough money to preserve the level of services.

About 55 percent of Christina's budget comes from state funding, while 38 percent comes from local property taxes (the rest comes from federal sources).

The state's share of school taxes grows as the district adds students, but the property tax revenue doesn't always do so.

Unlike many states, school taxes don't automatically adjust for inflation. So when costs of things like fuel and electricity go up, the money a district gets from property taxes buys less and less.

If more of the budget goes toward overhead, there is less available for educational programs.

That argument hasn't convinced some referendum opponents.

"They got $20 million five years ago – it didn't do anything," said Welsh. "So what's this $16 million going to do? There's no proof in the pudding."

A better system?

Michael Griffith, who studies school finance issues at the Colorado-based Education Commission of the States, said local school funding mechanisms vary widely from state to state. When it comes to picking the best method, he said figuring out "the one true religion is probably easier than this."

Most states require voter approval for school tax increases, he said. But many allow districts the choice to occasionally raise taxes by a small amount, usually tied to an inflation rate, without going to voters.

"If you believe in public education, as we do, the quality of our childrens' educational experience should not depend on a vote," Andrzejewski said. "There are very few states left in the country that require referendums for operating expenses."

Andrzejewski, who was previously Red Clay superintendent and has worked on several referendums, argues the state should move to a similar system. Delaware's vo-tech school districts, he points out, are given the ability to raise taxes up to a certain cap before getting the General Assembly's approval.

"There is a politically accepted, viable model that Delaware already has," Andrzejewski said. "School board members are elected officials just as the General Assembly is. They should be trusted to make a prudent financial decision on behalf of the community."

For taxpayers, Andrzejewski said a system like this would allow districts to raise taxes gradually over time, instead of periodically hitting them with one big increase all at once. Inflation rates are typically under two percent; by contrast, Christina is looking for a 21 percent increase in its tax rate.

There are two big caveats, Andrzejewski says.

First, school board members should be required to get financial training and should be penalized if they don't.

And second, districts should still be required to go to referendum for major new programs or building campaigns.

Are schools 'electioneering?

Another problem is Delaware districts are sometimes accused of employing underhanded tactics to get the votes they need.

The same day Christina's first referendum failed in 2015, Red Clay passed one. Almost immediately, some residents cried foul.

Many Red Clay schools held parent engagement events on the night of the vote in their buildings, which serve as polling places. Several older voters said those events crowded parking lots, denying them parking spaces that were close enough for them to make it in to vote. It also boosted turnout among parents.

An ACLU of Delaware lawsuit over those claims is still making its way through the courts. Red Clay maintains that it took sufficient steps to provide enough parking and argued it frequently holds events at schools to keep parents engaged in their kids' education.

STORY: Christina School District takes third try at referendum

STORY: UD to make SAT optional

State Sen. Karen Peterson, D-Stanton, received numerous complaints from constituents.

"Last year's Red Clay district referendum was the poster child for what's wrong with the whole system," Peterson said. "There was so much electioneering that went on inside the polling places that it was just an absolute disgrace."

Peterson says this isn't the first time a district has been accused of electioneering, referencing a so-called "Pizza-gate" incident a few years ago in which Smyrna schools threw pizza parties at schools on referendum night.

"I couldn't stand inside a polling place and hand out pizza if you voted for me," Peterson said.

Peterson has proposed a bill that would change how districts go out to referendums.

First, schools could only seek one referendum a year, at the same time as school board elections. That would save the state Department of Elections money and force districts to make one pitch for what they really need.

The fact that districts often come right back with referendum requests if a previous one fails upsets many opponents.

"If you say 'no' once, I mean 'no," Lulfs said. "You don't have to keep shoving it down my throat."

Peterson's bill would also have referendums conducted via mail. That would make more voters aware of the issues, she said, and prevent the inherent problems in having polling places that directly benefit from the results of a vote.

"We don't have to worry about all this going on at the schools," she said.

While Peterson argues these changes would make the system fairer, she agrees with some school supporters who say broader change is a good idea.

"These districts can get in a really bad place, because this is money they really do need," she said. "But you're asking people to vote for a tax on themselves. Something has to change."

search_result.title: Why a Lewes boy is throwing the first pitch at the Phillies' opener
search_result.text:
Update: The Phillies game has been postponed to Friday, March 29, at 3:05 p.m. Zeke Clark's surgery has been postponed, as well, so he can still throw the first pitch.

A Lewes 4-year-old who lost his lower leg in a lawnmower accident last year will throw the first pitch at the Phillies' season opener Friday.

Zeke Clark was riding on his father's lap in June 2023 when he jumped off, attempting to leap onto a picnic table bench, according to his mother, Maria Clark DeForrest. His right leg was severed below the knee. Since then, he's been a testament to children's resilience and optimism.

"He's not saying, 'I can't do this.' He's never once had a temper tantrum regarding his injuries. He's not thinking about it that way," Clark DeForrest said. "It's really helped us, too, as parents, to reconsider the way we think about unfortunate things that can happen in our lives."

Opening day postponed:Phillies' Opening Day game vs Braves postponed due to weather forecast; Here's the makeup date

Being chosen to throw the Phillies' first pitch is especially important to Clark and his family because he is scheduled for surgery the next day. His surgeon, Nemours' Dr. Jeanne Franzone, will join him on the mound.

"This gives us a great distraction," Clark DeForrest said. "I know he'll find comfort in knowing his surgeon is going to be celebrating with him at the game."

In addition to the amputation of his lower leg, Clark's femur was broken in the accident, and rods were surgically inserted to help the bone heal, according to Clark DeForrest. By October, Clark was in intensive therapy. He had just learned to walk again when doctors told his parents he'd need surgery again to remove the rods, among other things, Clark DeForrest said. That will mean a month or so in a wheelchair and learning to walk again.

Wilmington-area Nemours Children's Health, the recently announced "official children’s health partner of the Philadelphia Phillies," will host several promotions and events this year at Citizens Bank Park, including “Kids Run the Bases” on June 19 and July 31. The Phillies' opener against the Atlanta Braves starts at 3:05 p.m. Friday.

The Clark family continues to face the costs of a growing child with a prosthetic leg. Donations can be made at helphoplive.org/campaign/22355.

search_result.title: Delaware DOE points to a focus on literacy this budget season
search_result.text:
Top leaders in Delaware public schools have called the state's literacy scores unacceptable.

The department's budget hearing, in front of the Joint Finance Committee last week, called for a focus on boosting that performance across the First State — as DDOE looks at $2.1 billion in funding for the next fiscal year.

In this weekly roundup, we'll catch you up on this and other education updates you may have missed:

[Did we miss another good education story? Tell me about it: kepowers@gannett.com.]

Delaware Department of Education points to a focus on reading this budget season

Only 40% of students in grades third to eighth scored at or above proficiency in English language arts, in Delaware’s last state assessment results. At less than half, that's down two percentage points from 2022. And in the last 2022 NAEP scores, the state's fourth grade learners scored well below the national average in reading, ranking lower than 39 other jurisdictions.

Delaware's Department of Education pointed to as much in its own budget hearing last week.

"Let me be clear, our third grade literacy reading scores are not acceptable," Mark Holodick, state secretary of education, told lawmakers. He said the state must focus on boosting literacy. The discussion came among many topics in the JFC hearing — from the growing special education unit spending, to allowing districts to catch up to several curriculum-based bills, like the science of reading and Black history instruction.

Gov. John Carney is recommending $2.1 billion to DDOE in fiscal year '25, with some $3 million dogeared for early literacy coaches. That would fund 20 coaches to be deployed across schools as needed. This joins Delaware's framework of adding "high-impact tutoring" in many high-needs schools, having been one of five state's to receive $1 million in grant funds last year to fuel the integration.

Carney also included a first wave of recommendations from the Public Education Compensation Committee on salary increases across education employees, among other investments in a tight year.

MORE:Breaking down education funding in Delaware's proposed 2025 budget

Delaware State to host second annual conference aimed at supporting Black youth

Delaware State University's "Black Male Initiative" is a conference focused on supporting Black men from school to career. The event aims to gather high school students from across Delaware, business professionals, educators and community leaders to Dover for the second time.

This year's conference — "Empowering Excellence: Elevating Black Male Leadership in the 21st Century" — should kick off at 9 a.m. Thursday, Feb. 22.

"Attendees will be able to explore themes such as masculinity, personal identity, entrepreneurship and socioemotional learning," the website reads. "Through insightful workshops, inspiring keynote speakers and meaningful discussions, participants can gain valuable insights, develop a deeper understanding of their identity, and build the skills needed for personal and academic success."

Official registration has closed, per DSU's site, but there may still be sponsorship opportunities and other ways to get involved. Back in 2020, the Delaware HBCU's college of business was awarded a four-year, $900,000 grant to develop and execute the Black Male Initiative.

"Our participating students will be forever changed because of this award, our world-class College of Business, and (Executive Leadership Council)'s leadership," President Tony Allen said in a press release.

ICYMI:NBA star Magic Johnson helps Delaware State raise $3 million for scholarships in one night

UD touted as Fulbright top producer for the first time

University of Delaware was designated a "Fulbright Top Producer" by the U.S. Department of State’s Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs this month, for the first time in its history.

Fulbright is the country's flagship international exchange program, established back in 1946. These students get to study, teach and conduct research abroad. Alumni overall have included some 41 heads of state or government, 62 Nobel Laureates, 89 Pulitzer Prize winners, 80 MacArthur Fellows and more, according to the university.

Eleven UD students were selected for Fulbright awards this academic year, making the total for Delaware's largest university 100 recipients to date. Interest meetings and an application workshop for 2025-26 cycle applicants will be held this spring, according to UD.

"It is extremely fitting that in the year UD is celebrating its 100th anniversary of study abroad, we are also able to celebrate making Fulbright's top producer list,” said Michael Chajes, dean of UD’s Honors College, in a statement.

This joins a turbulent last month, having announced new budget tightening measures, alongside bracing for a possible "per-student tax" on the university from the City of Newark.
